newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Jan pulp stocks rise in Canada, Sweden, Finland.
newsitem.headline: Jan pulp stocks rise in Canada, Sweden, Finland.

text.p: Pulp stocks in Canada, Sweden and Finland rose by 106,000 tonnes in January, Norwegian forestry group Norske Skog said on Wednesday.
"No one is surprised about this," Claes-Inge Isacson, deputy managing director of Norske Skog, told Reuters.
U.S. figures are still missing, but they are expected to be published today. The U.S. increase could be between zero and 100,000 tonnes, Isacson said.
"They have said that they would halt production a few times in the U.S., so we will see," he said.
The figures should mean increased downward pressure on pulp prices. Officially long fibre pulp currently costs $560 a tonne, but several signs indicates the price is actually lower.
"There is a downward pressure," Isacson said. "From the $560 price valid at year end prices have come down by $10-20."
At the end of 1996, pulp inventories in the Norscan area, or Scandinavia and North America, amounted to roughly 1,900,000 tonnes.
